posts.name: 4907 mentor & enthusiast
posts.cooked:
When calibrating our LL4 using the info in the docs:

Why Does This Matter?

We are getting a reprojection error of between 1.4 and 1.6.  I’m wondering if anyone can shed some more light on what that means?  The docs say:

Check the Latest Calibration Result" card for a reasonable result with a low reprojection error (ideally less than 1)

Anybody have hints as to how we can get below 1 and also, what are the repercussions of having 1.5 or more?  It’s pretty hard for us to test the results as they are subtle but we’re hoping to improve our Megatag performance in some cases.  We’ve followed the directions as closely as possible with a printed 8.5x11 aruco tag printout from the LL site.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked:
A printed board won’t cut it. I had to buy a higher precision made Charuco board to achieve reprojection in the 0.5 px range.

https://www.etsy.com/listing/1820746969/charuco-calibration-target

CharuCo Targets CharuCo targets have uniquely coded fields, which makes it possible to calibrate using a partly occluded or with a non-ideal target location. It also improves robustness against image noise. These properties allow recording...

Price: EUR 116,00

Affordable Charuco Calibration Targets General Forum

Highly recommend this, they are relatively cheap but produce amazing results.

posts.name: Bjorn Janssen
posts.cooked: I don’t know if this will solve it, but I know that we experienced something similar when we flipped the width/height of the tiles on the board. So you might want to try to flip them in the calibration settings.

posts.name: 4907 mentor & enthusiast
posts.cooked: Ok, thank you!  Good for next year maybe.  I’m still wondering if my result (~1.6) is still better than using the default calibration though.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: I would say you’d have to output the estimation data pre-post calibration and empirically verify that yourself. My prior experience with Limelights was that the factory calibration was better than I could improve on my own, but that was before I purchased the boards I have now.

If you have a tablet to display the calibration board on you can get sub 1 fairly easily, since the screen is extremely flat. Just make sure to messure the size of elements on screen with calipers, since they likely won’t match a printed board.
